Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote on 08.07.2004 12:22:01:

> On Wednesday 07 July 2004 10:49 pm, Curt Sampson wrote:
[snip]
> >  I've been thinking for a while that this is a serious problem in 
JUnit
> >  (and most unit testing frameworks), because it's been such an 
annoyance
> >  for so many people. Let's face it; a lot of groups of tests do have
> >  known dependencies between tests such that if test A fails, we know 
that
> >  the output of tests B, C and D are uninteresting. Yet we end up 
running
> >  B, C and D anyway, and then searching through all the error output 
for
> >  the failure that we know is the "real" one, ignoring all the others 
as
> >  spurious.
> 
> With all due respect, I believe that is a code smell.  It seems to say 
to me 
> that there is something not right about the design of the code being 
tested, 
> or perhaps even more elusive, something is wrong with how the tests are 
> written.  When I find these types of dependencies I inevitably rethink 
how I 
> have written my tests.  Have I coded in the dependencies or are they 
really 
> there.  More times than not I have coded in the dependencies -- and 
therefore 
> I can remove them.  Further, I would argue that I _NEED_ to remove them. 
 
> Now, maybe I am old-fashioned but I believe tests (at least at the 
> unit/programmer level) ought to be as autonomous as possible.

I've heard that argument several times, and it sounds reasonable, but 
still I don't understand completely. I think the best way to present my 
confusion is to show to you an example where I think it would be perfectly 
reasonable to not run some tests, because I know the _will_ fail if one 
other fails:

I'm developing a system that handles (among others, but quite extensively) 
persistence of java objects to a database. I've built test cases for some 
(far too few, but that's another problem) of the functionality, most of 
which of course need a properly configured Database conection. Now I also 
got a test that checks to see if the system can successfully connect to 
the database. If this case fails then there are about 130 other tests that 
will not produce anything useable. It would probably be possible to mock 
the Database, but I can't really imagine how (without makeing the Mock so 
unstable, that it won't help).

What would you do about these tests in this case? Or am I talking about 
something completely different?

regards
Joachim Sauer
